I. 

THE PROPOSAL 

1. 
I  submit  for  your  approval  the  following  report  and  recommendation  on  (i)  a  proposed 
program loan, and (ii) a proposed project grant, both to the Lao People's Democratic Republic 
(Lao  PDR)  for  the  Basic  Education  Sector  Development  Program  (BESDP).  The  program 
design and monitoring framework is in Appendix 1.  

II. 

THE SECTOR: PERFORMANCE, PROBLEMS, AND OPPORTUNITIES 

A. 

Sector Description and Performance 

2. 
The Government of the Lao PDR accords high priority to education and recognizes that 
education and literacy are prerequisites for sustained economic growth and poverty reduction. 
This  is  emphasized  in  all  major  planning  documents  that  provide  a  vision  for  national 
development.  The  Government  adopted  the  Millennium  Development  Goals  in  2000  and  has 
articulated,  in  some  detail,  its  vision,  aspirations,  and  goals  for  education  development  in  a 
series of subsequent documents, which include (i) the Sixth Socio-Economic Development Plan, 
(ii) Education Sector Development Plan 2006–2010, (iii) Education Strategic Vision to 2020, and 
(iv) National Plan of Action for Education for All (EFA Plan).  
 
The  Government’s  key  goals  and  aspirations  for  education  include  (i)  universal  quality 
3. 
primary  education  and  continued  lower  secondary  expansion;  (ii)  eradication  of  illiteracy;  (iii) 
expansion of vocational, technical, and higher education to meet the demands of the new labor 
market and improve human capital rates of return; (iv) capacity development of skilled workers, 
technicians,  professionals,  and  intellectuals  to  use  modern  science  and  technology  to  serve 
development needs; (v) gradual improvement of the quality of national education to international 
standards; and (vi) establishment of education as a right and responsibility of all citizens. 

The Government’s strategy for strengthening education includes improving (i) access to 
4. 
education, particularly in remote areas; (ii) school participation and completion rates; and (iii) the 
quality  of  teaching  and  learning.  The  Government’s  priority  has  been  directed  to  ensuring 
equitable access to quality basic education (primary and lower secondary education [LSE]), to 
produce  quality  and  trainable  students  for  further  education  and  training.  The  EFA  Plan  is  the 
key document guiding the Government’s education development strategy and helping it fulfill its 
commitment to achieving universal primary education. 
 
The current education system comprises primary (grades 1–5), lower secondary (grades 
5. 
6–8), and upper secondary (grades 9-11); and beyond, fall within the ambit of tertiary education. 
To improve the efficiency of the education sector, the Government proposes to restructure the 
sector to (i) introduce a year of kindergarten, (ii) extend LSE by including grade 9 (grades 6–9); 
and (iii) extend upper secondary education to include grade 12 (grades 10–12). The introduction 
of  kindergarten  will  rationalize  enrolments  in  grade  1,  and  restructuring  lower  and  upper 
secondary education will bring it in line with prevailing international norms of a 12-year school 
cycle.  
 
6. 
Since  1990,  the  Government  has  made  considerable  progress  in  improving  access  to 
education, particularly in primary education. Between 1990 and 2005, the net enrollment ratio1 
(NER) for primary education increased by more than 16% from 63% to approximately 79%. The 

                                                 
1   NER refers to pupils enrolled from the eligible age group. 

 2 

 

gross  enrollment  ratio2 increased  from  30%  in  1990  to  51%  in  2005  for  lower  secondary,  and 
from  26.3%  in  2003  to  31%  in  2005  for  upper  secondary.  With  more  than  an  8%  increase 
annually, the number of secondary students has been growing at four times the rate of primary 
school students.  

7. 
Girls’  enrollment  has  also  shown  rapid  progress.  Gender  differentials  in  primary 
enrollment  have  dropped  by  7.4%  since  1996  (from  21.6%  to  14.2%).  Girls’  secondary 
enrollment increased by more than 4% between 2003 and 2005 compared with a 1.9% increase 
for  boys.  During  the  same  period,  girls’  upper  secondary  enrollment  increased  by  4.4% 
compared with a 5.1% increase for boys. Even so, significant gender differentials remain: girls’ 
primary enrollment lags boys’ by approximately 14% and girls’ secondary enrollment lags boys’ 
by more than 12%.  

8. 
Extensive  funding  agency  support,  almost  all  concentrating  on  the  primary  education, 
has fueled the primary expansion. Expanding primary enrollments have led to growing demand 
for  secondary  education.  During  1990–2005,  LSE  expanded  by  more  than  20%.  Upper 
secondary  enrollments  increased  more  than  4.5%  between  2003  and  2005.  Though  overall 
lower  and  upper  secondary  enrollments  are  low,  both  are  registering  high  rates  of  growth.  If 
primary education absorbs all external funding, subsequent levels of education will continue to 
be  neglected.  This  will create  an  imbalance  in  the  education  sector  with  serious  ramifications. 
First, the gains from increased primary enrollments will be lost if the lower secondary and upper 
secondary subsectors are not ready to absorb the primary school graduates who may want to 
pursue further schooling. Second, quality and access issues become much more of a challenge 
with increasing numbers of students. Expansion in enrollment has not been complemented by 
corresponding improvements in quality, and the internal efficiency of education remains weak. 

9. 
In  keeping  with  educational  trends  in  developing  economies,  demand  for  education 
within all education subsectors will continue to grow rapidly. The Education Sector Development 
Plan identifies targets for each education subsector that are linked to expansion of enrollment 
as well as improved efficiencies within the system. The main challenges in the education sector 
are to (i) meet the growing demand for education; (ii) address issues of access and equity, and 
(iii)  improve  the  internal  efficiency  of  the  system.  However,  resource  constraints  and  weak 
capacity  limit  the  Government’s  ability  to  provide  the  inputs  necessary  for  achieving  its 
quantitative and qualitative goals for education development.   
 
B. 

Issues and Opportunities 

10. 
An analysis of the performance of the education system and identification of key issues 
highlights, among others, (i) unequal participation in schooling because of social, economic, and 
geographic  disparities;  and  (ii)  low  internal  efficiency  reflected  by  high  dropout  and  repetition

1. 

Access and Equity 

Despite  rapid  enrollment  growth,  universal  access  at  primary  schools  remains  a  major 
11. 
challenge. Approximately 23% of primary school-age children are not enrolled in school. Among 
those who do enroll, over 8% drop out. National enrollment statistics hide disparities that exist in 
access by geographic region, socioeconomic status, gender, and ethnicity at all levels of school 
education.  Access  to  schooling  in  remote  rural  regions  continues  to  be  limited  compared  with 
access in urban, better-developed areas. For example, Luang Namtha Province has the lowest

NER  of  95%  for  girls  and  92%  for  boys.  Although  enrollments  among  the  disadvantaged  and 
poorer groups are growing at a faster rate than enrollments among the more advantaged groups, 
the  percentage  of  poorer  children  who  continue  to  be  out  of  school  is  still  greater  than  the 
percentage of children from economically better-off groups. 

12. 
Physical access remains a major barrier. Approximately 15% of villages are still without 
a primary school within commutable distance.3 Approximately 70% of the schools in the poorest 
districts are incomplete schools, only offering classes up to grade 2 or 3. Fifty-seven percent of 
all primary schools and an estimated 70%–80% of schools in the poorest districts do not offer 
the  full  five  grades  of  primary  education.  Low  population  density  and  remoteness  make 
provision  of  cost-effective  and  sustainable  education  services  difficult  in  remote  rural  areas. 
Thus,  children  in  the  poorest  areas,  particularly  girls  and  ethnic  groups,  are  distinctly 
disadvantaged in terms of limited access to education.  

13. 
Enrollment  statistics  reflect  the  impact  of  gender-differentiated  access.  The  NER  in 
primary schools for girls is 49% in rural areas without access to roads, 72.2% in rural areas with 
access  to  roads,  and  90.5%  in  urban  areas.  Corresponding  statistics  for  boys  are  56%,  75%, 
and 88%. Substantial gender disparities persist in rural areas, where girls’ enrollment is growing 
at a much slower rate than that of boys. Primary completion rates are also lower for girls at 48% 
compared  with  52%  for  boys.  This  gap  persists  in  enrollments  into  entry  grades  at  lower  and 
upper secondary. Predictably, transition rates are higher in urban, nonpoor areas as compared 
with the poorer areas, though the gap is narrowing rapidly.  

In  the  case  of  lower  and  upper  secondary  education,  rapid  expansion  has  not  been 
14. 
matched by increased availability of schools with adequate facilities or qualified teachers. The 
demand for additional secondary space has been met by overcrowding in the classrooms or by 
use  of  derelict,  abandoned  school  buildings  that  were  replaced  by  new  buildings  provided 
through  externally  funded  projects  or  by  poaching  space  of  nearby  primary  schools.  This  has 
resulted  in  a  shortage  of  primary  teachers  and  overcrowded,  poorly  equipped  primary 
classrooms.  The  result  for  secondary  schools  is  inadequately  qualified  teachers,  increasing 
class sizes, and shortage of classrooms. This has multiple negative impacts on quality. 

2. 

Quality 

15. 
Quality is a function of internal systemic efficiencies. The Lao National Literacy Survey 
found that primary education does not ensure the acquisition of basic literacy. Just over 50% of 
primary  graduates  (grade  5  completers)  attain  basic  literacy.  Similarly,  only  38%  of  nonformal 
education  level  III  completers  (equivalent  to  primary  graduates)  attain  basic  literacy.  Internal 
efficiency of the education system has been improving since 1995/96, with a significant decline 
in repetition rates for all grades, especially grade 5. However, repetition and dropout rates are 
still high in grades 1 and 2. About 33% of students in primary school repeat grade 1 and another 
19% repeat grade 2.4 Completion rates for primary education are estimated at 48% for females 
and  52%  for  males.  Repetition  rates  vary  across  poverty  levels.  High  repetition  and  dropout 
rates,  particularly  for  the  lower  grades,  and  an  average  of  8  years  to  complete  primary 
education  are  indicators  of  low  internal  efficiency  and  poor  quality  of  education.  Internal 
efficiency improves after grade 4 with repetition and dropout rates declining, and improves again

Rapid  expansion  of  postprimary  education  under  severe  financial  constraints  has  also 
had a negative impact on its quality. Average class sizes have grown, especially in grades 9–11, 
where  the  national  average  reached  81  pupils  per  class  in  2004/05.  Large  class  size  is  a

additional  secondary  teachers  has  been  partly  met  by  transference  of  primary  teachers  to

primary  class  sizes.  Teacher  training  is  being  addressed  through  funding  agency  support  and 
the Government has prepared a teacher education strategy and action plan.5 However, a policy 
framework for teacher recruitment and deployment to ensure the supply of qualified teachers is 
still lacking.  

17. 
Lack  of  adequate  provision  of  textbooks  and  learning  materials  is  also  a  major 
contributor  to  weak  quality.  Most  schools  have  insufficient  textbooks  and  few,  if  any,  learning 
materials or teacher guides. In fact, limited availability of books in primary and lower secondary 
schools is the most commonly cited problem for Lao schools. An education sector analysis is in

3. 

Finances 

Resource allocations for education declined sharply in 1997 from 15% of the budget to a 
18. 
low of 8%. The Government has agreed to raise the allocation to 16% by 2010 taking education 
expenditures to over 3% of gross domestic product (GDP), from its current 2.5%. This would be 
in line with expenditures of other developing countries. Funding agencies contribute, on average, 
approximately 75% of capital investments in education. These investments create a demand for 
recurrent  expenditures  that  the  Government  has  not  been  able  to  meet,  thus  creating  an 
imbalance in the ratio of capital and recurrent expenditures. While most countries in the region 
assign about 70% of their education budget to recurrent expenditures, the recurrent share in the 
Lao  PDR  is  little  more  than  40%.  The  average  salary  of  a  primary  teacher  amounts  to  0.65% 
GDP/capita  compared  with  a  regional  average  of  2.0–2.5  GDP/capita.  Continued  capital 
investments  without  matching  provision  for  recurrent  costs  are  likely  to  result  in  expanding 
access through increased supply of schools but with chronic shortage of recurrent resources for 
teachers’  salaries  and  provision  of  textbooks,  teaching-learning  materials,  and  other  school 
supplies. This imbalance between the recurrent and capital expenditures needs to be corrected 
and a more sustainable ratio obtained (70:30).

The  Government  bases  its  current  strategies  for  education  development  on  the  three

learning  achievement;  (iv)  reduction  of  adult  illiteracy;  (v)  expansion  of  basic  education  and 
training  in  essential  skills  required  by  youths  and  adults;  and  (vi)  increased  acquisition  by

21.  Within  the  Education  for  All  framework,  the  Government  hopes  to  improve  the  quality

27.

Impact and Outcome

51.  MOE’s  national  target  is  to  increase  the  transition  rate  from  primary  education  to  LSE

secondary school prevents girls and the poorest ethnic pupils from being admitted into LSE. In 
addition,  high  demand  for  LSE  in  urban  areas  has  created  strong  pressure  on  urban  lower 
secondary  schools.  A  balance  must  therefore  be  found  between  increasing  opportunities  for 
girls and the poorest ethnic pupils, while responding to sustained demand from nonpoor pupils.

IV. 

PROGRAM BENEFITS, IMPACTS, ASSUMPTIONS, AND RISKS 

A. 

Benefits 

88. 
A well-educated population and work force is necessary for sustained economic growth. 
In an increasingly competitive environment, educational attainment beyond primary is important 
for  most  of  the  population.  LSE  lays  the  foundations  for  acquisition  of  basic  cognitive  skills, 
which  are  essential  for  productivity  as  well  as  for  enhancing  basic  welfare;  and  increases  the 
transition  rates  to  secondary  and  other  higher  levels  of  education.  For  the  Lao  PDR,  where 
participation  rates  and  quality  of  educational  achievements  are  still  low,  investments  in 
improving  access  to  and  quality  of  education  can  have  significant  positive  gains,  both 
economically and socially.  
 
Economic  Benefits.  The  economic  benefits  from  the  BESDP  will  be  two  fold.  First, 
89. 
substantial economic benefits are expected to accrue from efficiency gains. Improved quality of 
education  will  lead  to  reductions  in  dropout  and  repetition  rates.  These  reductions  will  reduce 
waste and result in lower per capita expenditures in education. Interventions aimed at systemic 
improvements  to  strengthen  planning  and  management,  particularly  to  effect  more  rational 
recruitment and deployment of teachers will enhance economic efficiency through more efficient 
use of scarce resources. Similarly, a more equitable distribution of physical facilities based on 
enrollments  will  lead  to  more  efficient  use  of  resources.  Overall  increased  access  will  expand 
coverage of education, with increased enrollments, increasing the number of beneficiaries and 
leading to more students graduating to higher levels of education.  
 
90. 
Second,  students  who  do  not  drop  out  in  any  given  year  increase  their  wage-earning 
potential.  Studies  indicate  that  each  extra  year  of  schooling  increases  labor  productivity  and 
earning  potential.  Thus,  students  are  able  to  get  a  higher  return  from  their  investment  in 
education. Improved quality of LSE will encourage more primary school completers to continue 

 

 their  studies,  resulting  in  higher  educational  attainment  thereby  increasing  their  earning 
potential. The scholarships provided under the program to girls and ethnic students will attract 
children  from  these  groups  to  continue  their  education  in  LSE.  This  will  enhance  their 
productivity and earning capability resulting in a positive impact on their families, helping them 
to break out of the cycle of poverty.  
 
91. 
Social  Benefits.  Society  derives  substantial  gains  from  increases  in  education 
attainment,  particularly  basic  education.  Improvements  in  human  development  indicators  are 
directly linked to level of education attainment. Social benefits are highest from investments in 
girls’  education  and  have  particular  significance  because  they  are  intergenerational.  Educated 
women have fewer children; provide better nutrition for their children leading to improved family 
health;  and  provide  for  fairer  and  more  equitable  intrahousehold  allocation  of  resources, 
reducing  future  gender  disparities.  Studies  indicate  that  educated  mothers  tend  to  use  health 
services more frequently, thereby increasing efficiencies of health care investments. Substantial 
benefits  will  also  accrue  from  reduced  risk  of  vulnerability  to  HIV/AIDS,  child  labor  and 
trafficking, especially in cross-border areas. Social gains from lower rates of population growth, 
healthier  households,  and  a  better  educated  population  also  imply  significant  economic  gains 
since the state has to invest less in expansion of basic services (health and education) and can 
instead focus on improvements in quality.  
 
The  BESDP  will  expand  access  for  children  in  ethnic  areas  and  improve  facilities  in 
92. 
needy  schools  through  the  provision  of  block  grants.  Enhanced  opportunities  for  improved 
quality  of  education  for  ethnic  children  will,  in  the  long  term,  contribute  to  reduced  economic 
disparities resulting in greater integration and social harmony. Populations also benefit from the 
demonstration  effect  of  increased  education  attainment,  resulting  in  greater  demand  for 
education as well as adoption of more progressive social habits and dispersal of knowledge on 
key social issues.  
 
Institutional Benefits. Direct systemic benefits to the education sector will accrue from 
93. 
the policy reforms supported by the BESDP. The policy areas and supporting capacity building, 
which  will  lead  to  substantial  long-term  efficiencies,  include  (i)  a  rational  and  standardized 
process for planning and budget preparation; and (ii) development of an MTEF for the education 
sector  that  will  feed  into  the  national  MTEF.  Resource  efficiencies  will  also  accrue  from 
development  of  a  policy  framework  for  the  recruitment  and  deployment  of  teachers  that  will 
promote efficient use of available teaching personnel. An improved EMIS, including a TMIS and 
a FMIS, will enable more precise planning and management resulting in efficiencies in allocation 
as well as utilization of scarce resources. These policy measures will help sustain interventions 
that support expansion and quality of education.  
 
94. 
The BESDP will have national, provincial, and district institutional benefits. It will support 
decentralized planning and management capability through the design and piloting of systems 
for  budget  preparation,  financial  reporting,  and  implementation  at  all  levels  of  education 
management. It will support clear delineation and strengthening of the roles and responsibilities 
of provincial and district education bodies. The Project will enhance capacity for data collection, 
management,  and  analysis.  MOE’s  inventory  system  will  be  strengthened  to  allow  for  better 
asset  management.  These  inputs  will  also  lead  to  economic  benefits  derived  from  efficiencies 
gained through improved planning and management capacity.

Risks 

95. 
The  BESDP  was  designed  to  support  the  Government’s  goals  for  expansion  and 
strengthening  of  the  education  sector.  The  Government  has  shown  strong  commitment  to 
education  and  accords  it  high  priority  as  a  key  sector  for  economic  development  and  poverty 
reduction.  Even  so,  limited  leadership  and  ownership  of  the  policy  reform  process  and  lack  of 
consistency in policy and strategic decision-making pose potential risks. These will be mitigated 
through  (i)  the  ongoing  review  and  assessment  process  by  MOE  officials  and  the  EDWG, 
including nongovernment organizations to secure broad support for the reform agenda; (ii) the 
annual BESDP review process, which will facilitate a phased and sequenced approach to policy 
implementation;  and  (iii)  technical  support  under  the  BESDP  as  well  as  advisory  support  by 
ADB25 and  other  development  partners  for  ongoing  policy  studies  and  related  legislative  and 
regulatory reforms.  
 
96.  MOE’s limited capacity to manage and implement the revised policies and strategies is 
another  potential  risk.  This  will  be  mitigated  by  (i)  helping  MOE  to  strengthen  systems  for 
decentralized  planning  and  management,  and  (ii)  providing  extensive  advisory  support  for 
subsector  and  program  planning  and  management.  Consulting  services  supported  by  the 
BESDP  will  also  help  the  Government  ensure  that  an  appropriate  legislative  and  regulatory 
framework is in place, as agreed in the policy matrix.  
 
97. 
Limitations  in  tax  recovery,  uncertainties  in  future  aid  agency  funding,  and  unforeseen 
developments  pose  potential  risks  that  may  undermine  the  predictability  of  Government 
resources  available  for  education,  especially  the  significant  transitional  costs  associated  with 
policy  reforms.  This  potential  risk  will  be  mitigated  through  (i)  extensive  dialogue  on  medium-
term resource availability for education between MOE and funding agencies within the EDWG; 
(ii) using the MTEF process as a basis for identifying potential budget shortfalls and mobilizing 
increased sector budget support; (iii) extensive sector efficiency measures to improve efficiency 
of  resource  use;  and  (iv)  strong  policy  linkage  with  the  Government’s  broader  public  financial 
management  reforms.  Resource  constraints  may  also  limit  the  ability  of  the  Government  to 
redress  the  imbalance  in  favor  of  capital  expenditures.  However,  Government  revenues  are 
expected  to  increase  in  the  future.  The  Government  has  committed  to  providing  revenues 
generated  by  the  Nam  Theun  2  Project  to  spending  on  the  social  sectors. 26  Increased 
availability of resources for social sectors will allow for a more balanced allocation of resources.

EDUCATION SECTOR ANALYSIS 

 
1. 
Overview.  Considerable  progress  has  been  made  in  improving  access  to  education  in 
the  Lao  People’s  Democratic  Republic  (Lao  PDR)  in  recent  years,  particularly  in  primary 
education. Net enrollment ratios1 (NERs) for primary education increased from 63% in 1990 to 
approximately  79%  in  2005.  Similarly,  gross  enrollment  ratios2 for  lower  secondary  increased 
from 30% in 1990 to 51% in 2005; and, for upper secondary from 26.3% in 2003 to 31% in 2005. 
With a more than 8 % annual increase, the number of secondary students has been growing at 
four times the rate of primary school students.  

2. 
Girls’  enrollment  has  also  shown  rapid  progress.  Gender  differentials  in  primary 
enrollments have dropped by 7.4%  since 1996 (from 21.6% to 14.2%).  Girls’ lower secondary 
enrollments increased by more than 4% between 2003 and 2005 compared with 1.9% for boys. 
During  the  same  period,  girls’  upper  secondary  enrollment  increased  by  4.4%  compared  with 
5.1%  for  boys.  Even  so,  significant  gender  differentials  remain:  primary  school  enrollment  for 
girls lags boys by approximately 14%; secondary school enrollment for girls lags boys by more 
than 12%. 

3. 
Despite the rapid expansion of school education, the education sector is weak and faces 
considerable  challenges  in  addressing  sector  needs.  In  keeping  with  educational  trends  in 
developing economies, demand for education within all subsectors will continue to grow rapidly. 
The  Government,  in  its  draft  Sixth  National  Socio-Economic  Development  Plan  (2006–2010), 
provides  targets  for  each  educational  subsector  linked  to  expansion  of  enrollment  as  well  as 
improved  efficiencies  within  the  system.  The  main  challenges  will  be  to  meet  the  growing 
demand for education, address equity issues, and improve internal efficiency of the system. 

4. 
Access  and  Equity.  Despite  rapid  enrollment  growth,  universal  access  to  primary 
education remains a major challenge: approximately 23% of primary school-age children are not 
enrolled  in  school.  Among  those  who  enroll,  more  than  8%  drop  out.  National  enrollment 
statistics  hide  the  disparities  that  exist  in  access  by  geographic  region,  socioeconomic  status, 
and ethnicity. The NER for girls is primary schools is 49% in rural areas without access to roads, 
72.2% in rural areas with access to roads, and 90.5% in urban areas. Luangnamtha Province 
has the lowest primary NER for girls at 43% and boys at 48.6%. By comparison, Vientiane City 
has the highest NER of 95% for girls and 92% for boys. Similar disparities exist at the lower and 
upper secondary levels.  

When enrollments reach high levels, growth rates tend to decline. This is true in the Lao 
5. 
PDR where enrollment trends, particularly for primary education, indicate overall declining rates 
of  increase.  Enrollment  growth  is  declining  in  high-income  areas  and  increasing  rapidly  in  the 
poor and poorest areas. In the high-income areas, enrollments are already relatively high and 
birthrates are declining, whereas in the poorer areas the potential for growth is greater because 
of the initial low threshold, birthrates continue to be high, and also possibly because externally 
funded  projects  have  targeted  poorer  areas  for  expanded  access  to  primary  education.  Low 
enrollment  is  also  responsible  for  high  rates  of  expansion  for  lower  and  upper  secondary 
education.  

6. 
Physical access continues to be a barrier for primary education—approximately 15% of 
villages  are  still  without  a  primary  school  within  commutable  distance.  Further,  approximately 
70%  of  schools  in  the  poorest  districts  are  incomplete  schools,  only  offering  classes  up  to

7. 
Quality.  Quality  aspects  of  school  education  remain  a  serious  concern.  Quality  is  a 
function  of  internal  systemic  efficiencies.  The  Lao  National  Literacy  Survey  found  that  primary 
education does not ensure the acquisition of basic literacy. Just over 50% of primary graduates 
(grade  5  completers)  attain  basic  literacy.  Similarly,  only  38%  of  nonformal  education  level  III 
completers  (equivalent  to  primary  graduates)  attain  basic  literacy.  Internal  efficiency  of  the 
education  system  has  been  improving  since  1995/96,  with  a  significant  decline  in  repetition 
rates  for  all  grades,  especially  grade  5.  However,  repetition  and  dropout  rates  are  still  high  in 
grades  1  and  2.  About  33%  of  students  in  primary  school  repeat  grade  1  and  another  19% 
repeat grade 2. Completion rates for primary education are estimated at 48% for females and 
52%  for  males.  Repetition  rates  vary  across  poverty  levels.  High  repetition  and  dropout  rates, 
particularly at the lower grades, and an average of 8 years to complete primary education are 
indications  of  low  internal  efficiency  and  poor  quality  education.  Internal  efficiency  improves 
after  grade  4  with  repetition  and  dropout  rates  declining.  Internal  efficiency  is  higher  for 
secondary education with lower dropout and repetition rates. However, rapid expansion without 
adequate emphasis on strengthening quality will cause efficiency declines. Factors contributing 
to poor quality of education are (i) lack of adequate supply of qualified teachers; (ii) shortage of 
textbooks  and  other  learning  materials;  (iii)  curriculum  deficiencies;  (iv)  low  recurrent 
expenditures;  and  (v)  weak  institutional  capacity  for  planning,  management,  and  delivery  of 
education. 

8. 
Education service delivery is still uneven and the quality of education has not caught up 
with the rapid expansion of the system, creating an imbalance, particularly among poor people 
living in rural ethnic villages. Rapid expansion of postprimary education under severe financial 
constraints has had a negative impact on quality. Average class sizes have grown, especially in 
grades  9  to  11,  where  the  national  average  reached  81  pupils  per  class  in  2004/05.  The 
demand for additional secondary teachers has been partly met by transferring primary teachers 
to secondary schools. This has led to underqualified teachers at secondary schools and larger 
class  sizes  at  primary  schools  (see  also  para.  6).  The  transfer  of  teachers  from  primary  to 
secondary could have a negative impact on achievement of Education for All goals. However, 
large  class  sizes  are  not  entirely  a  result  of  lack  of  teachers  but  also  of  inadequate  physical 
facilities  to  accommodate  the  larger  numbers,  leading  to  overcrowding  in  limited  classroom 
space.  

9. 
Lack  of  adequate  textbooks  and  learning  materials  is  also  a  major  contributor  to  weak 
quality. In fact, limited availability of books in primary and lower secondary schools is the most 
commonly  cited  problem  for  Lao  schools.  Most  schools  have  insufficient  textbooks  and  few,  if 
any, learning materials. Overall teacher qualifications are low. Nationally, 22% of teachers have 
completed only primary education; more than 20% have had no training, and a high proportion 
of  these  untrained  teachers  are  in  remote  areas.  Teacher  training,  another  key  element  for 
quality  of  education,  is  being  addressed  through  funding  agency  support  and  a  formal  school 
teacher  training  plan  is  in  the  final  stages  of  preparation.  However,  a  policy  framework  for

Finance. Resource allocations declined sharply in 1997 from a 15% share of the budget 
to  a  low  of  8%.  The  Government  has  agreed  to  raise  the  allocations  to  16%  by  2010  taking 
education  expenditures  to  more  than  3%  of  gross  domestic  product  (GDP),  from  the  current 
2.5%. This would be in line with expenditures of other developing countries. Funding agencies 
contribute,  on  average,  approximately  75%  of  capital  investments  in  education.  These 
investments create a demand for recurrent expenditures that the Government has not been able 
to  meet,  thus  creating  an  imbalance  in  the  ratio  of  capital  and  recurrent  expenditures.  While 
most  countries  in  the  region  assign  about  70%  of  their  education  budget  to  recurrent 
expenditures, the recurrent share for the Lao PDR is little more than 40%. The average salary of 
a  primary  teacher  amounts  to  0.65%  GDP/capita  compared  with  a  regional  average  of  2.0%–
2.5%  GDP/capita.  Continued  capital  investments  are  likely  to  result  in  increasing  physical 
coverage of schools, but with chronic shortage of recurrent resources for teachers’ salaries and 
provision  of  textbooks  and  supplies.  This  imbalance  between  the  recurrent  and  capital 
expenditures needs to be corrected and a more sustainable ratio obtained (i.e., 70:30).

Government Objectives and Strategic Priorities. Since 2000, the Government of the 
Lao  PDR  has  demonstrated  continued  commitment  to  pro-poor  development,  with  the 
elaboration  of  the  National  Poverty  Eradication  Program,  supported  by  a  broad  external 
assistance program and followed by the design of the National Growth and Poverty Eradication 
Strategy (June 2004). The Government’s goals for education and training include the following:3 
(i)  universalizing  quality  primary  education  and  continuing  expansion  of  lower  secondary 
education; (ii) eradicating illiteracy; (iii) expanding vocational, technical, and higher education to 
meet  the  demands  of  the  new  labor  market,  and  improving  human  capital  rates  of  return;  (iv)

modern science and technology to serve development needs; (v) gradually improving the quality 
of  national  education  to  international  standards;  and  (vi)  establishing  education  as  a  right  and 
responsibility of all people in society. The Government’s priority is to ensure equitable access to 
quality  basic  education  (primary  and  lower  secondary),  and  produce  quality  and  trainable 
students for further education and training.

The Lao PDR has undergone rapid economic development and growth over the last decade. Gross domestic product 
(GDP)  has  improved  with  an  average  GDP  per  capita  of  $207  (1990)  to  $428  (2004)  (National  Statistics  Center

2.0%  (1995–2005),  the  absolute  increase  of  population  was  1.04  million  (1995–2005)—an  average  increase  of 
100,000  per  year.  Over  the  past  two  decades,  the  urban  population  increased  (from  17%–27%),  while  the  rural 
decreased (from 83% to 73%).  
 
While most socioeconomic indicators have consistently improved over the past few years, inequalities exist in social 
and economic development throughout the Lao PDR. The gap of inequality in income per capita seems to be widening 
between  urban  and  rural  areas.  Income  disparities  have  been  widening  between  provinces,  districts,  and  ethnic 
groups,  with  the  most  vulnerable  groups  including  ethnic  groups  found  in  remote  rural  areas.  The  total  population 
under the age of 15 decreased from 44% in 1995 to about 39%. About 57% of individuals (aged 15–64) are working—
an  increase  from  52%  in  1995.  Agricultural  workers  account  for  about  76%—a  decrease  from  about  85%  in  1995 
(Population and Housing Census, 2005). 
 
Poverty incidence (i.e., percentage of the population  with  consumption below the poverty line) dropped from 45% to 
38.6%  when  GDP  growth  averaged  7%  (Lao  Expenditure  and  Consumption  Survey  1992/93  and  1997/98).  At  the 
same time, inequality increased with a Gini index increase from 29% to 36%. In 2002/03, poverty incidence dropped to 
32%. This reduction was associated with strong economic growth, achievement of rice self-sufficiency and increased 
cross-border trade. However, the Lao PDR remains a least developed country, as it ranks 131 out of 177 countries in 
the  2005  Human  Development  Report  of  the  United  Nations  Development  Program.  Studies  suggest  that  education 
and literacy are key factors in achieving sustained economic growth, poverty reduction, and gender equality. An extra 
year  of  schooling  is  seen  to  increase  labor  productivity  and  earning  potential.  Thus,  better  education  and  training

In 2005, educational attainment of employed females in the labor force was (i) 6.1% for lower secondary; (ii) 1.3% for 
upper  secondary;  and  (iii)  7.7%  for  technical/vocational  qualification,  college  diploma,  and  university  degree. 
Educational attainment  was comparatively higher for employed males: 8.6%, 2.2%, and 14.1%. A gender imbalance 
exists in accessing primary education and LSE. Girl’s enrollment in primary school lags that of boys’ by approximately 
14%, and in LSE by more than 12%. The net enrollment ratio for girls is also influenced by access in rural and urban 
areas: for primary education it is estimated at 49% for girls in rural areas without road access. (56% for boys), 72% in 
rural areas with road access (75% for boys), and 91% in urban areas (88% for boys). This leads to lower completion 
rates in primary education for girls (47%) compared with boys (52%). These differentials continue for lower and upper 
secondary education.  
 
The  low  rate  of  female  enrolment  in  lower  secondary  school  leads  to  a  significantly  lower  number  of  female 
enrolments  in  teacher  training  colleges,  and  subsequently,  low  representation  in  the  field  of  teaching,  particularly  in 
lower  and  upper  secondary  schools.  Gender  equality  issues  need  to  be  better  integrated  and  addressed,  especially 
human  resource  development  issues  for  ethnic  groups,  in  official  education  and  training  policies,  teacher  training 
program development, and project activities.
